title: "The Mythical Sword and its Role in Arthurian Lore"
first_phrase: In the previous text, we read about the sword that was blamed for the devastation of the Logres kingdom because of King Urban's betrayal's murder. In the Morte Darthur, Sir Balin le Savage emerges a character who aces the test of drawing the sword from a doncella, but refutes to return it to the woman, causing his own downfall. He defeats the King Pellan with a magical spear placed beside the sword. However, He couldn't distinguish his brother Balan and died in his hands. Now, in the next part, we will explore how the sword's curse and Sir Galahad will play a vital role in curing King Pellan.
content: Balin ha de combatir con el rey Pellan: la espada se le rompe, busca otra arma, encuentra una lanza maravillosa sobre una mesa de oro, con ella hiere a Pellan, quien cae sin sentido y no sanará, «hasta que venga Galahad, el alto príncipe, a sanarlo con la búsqueda del Sangreal». Junto a la mesa, sobre un lecho, yacía el propio José de Arimatea, postrado por la edad. Ese es el golpe doloroso que destruye en parte el reino de Logres y trae una especie de Némesis. En efecto, Balin acaba combatiendo contra su propio hermano, Balan, sin reconocerlo, y ambos se matan uno al otro.
last_phrase: In conclusion, the story of Balin and his journey is a cautionary tale of how the pursuit of power and the usurpation of authority can lead to tragic consequences, and how true strength lies not in physical might, but in nobility of heart and purpose. The legacy of the sword is a reminder that power should not be taken lightly, and that only those who are truly worthy can wield it with honor and righteousness.
